cheatsheet:
Basics
- print(...) outputs text to the console
- Code runs top to bottom
hints: Use print(...) to show text in the console.
Pay attention to capitalization and punctuation.
lesson:
Lesson: Basics
Print "Hello, Forge" to the console

Overview:
- print(...) outputs text to the console
- Code runs top to bottom

Practice:
- Implement the TODOs.
- Press Enter to run the check.
- Use `h` for hints and `c` for cheatsheet when stuck.
solution: print("Hello, Forge")
title: Hello, Forge

cheatsheet:
Comments
- Single-line: // comment
- Multi-line: /* comment */
- Comments are ignored by the compiler
description: Add comments to make code clear and document your work
hints: Single-line comments start with //.
Multi-line comments use /* */ and can span lines.
Make sure the program prints two lines total.
lesson:
Lesson: Comments
Comments are notes for humans. The compiler ignores them.

Overview:
- Use comments to clarify intent, assumptions, or tricky logic.
- Avoid narrating obvious code.

Single-line comments:
    // This line explains the next step
    let heat = 1500

Multi-line comments:
    /*
     Use a block comment for longer notes
     or to temporarily disable a block.
     */

Good comment examples:
- Why a decision was made
- A non-obvious edge case
- The goal of a block of logic
title: Comments

cheatsheet:
Variables
- let creates a constant
- var creates a variable
- Type annotation: let x: Int = 5
- Swift infers types from values
hints: Constants are declared with let.
print(...) outputs a value to the console.
lesson:
Lesson: Constants, Variables, and Types
Swift stores values in constants (`let`) and variables (`var`).

Overview:
- Use `let` when a value should not change.
- Use `var` when you plan to update the value.
- Every value has a type, and Swift enforces type safety.

Constants vs variables:
    let maxTemp = 1600
    var currentTemp = 1200
    currentTemp = 1400

Type annotation:
- You can declare a type explicitly when you want clarity.
    let count: Int = 3
    let name: String = "Forge"

Type inference:
- Swift can infer the type from the assigned value.
    let ratio = 0.25      // Double
    let enabled = true    // Bool

Common types:
- Int: whole numbers (e.g., 42)
- Double: decimals (e.g., 3.14)
- String: text (e.g., "steel")
- Bool: true/false

Rule of thumb:
- Prefer `let` by default; switch to `var` only when you need mutation.
solution:
let forgeTemperature = 1500
print(forgeTemperature)
title: Constants

cheatsheet:
Variables
- let creates a constant
- var creates a variable
- Type annotation: let x: Int = 5
- Swift infers types from values
hints: var is for values that can change.
Reassignment updates the stored value.
lesson:
Lesson: Constants, Variables, and Types
Swift stores values in constants (`let`) and variables (`var`).

Overview:
- Use `let` when a value should not change.
- Use `var` when you plan to update the value.
- Every value has a type, and Swift enforces type safety.

Constants vs variables:
    let maxTemp = 1600
    var currentTemp = 1200
    currentTemp = 1400

Type annotation:

    let name: String = "Forge"

Type inference:
- Swift can infer the type from the assigned value.

    let enabled = true    // Bool

Common types:
- Int: whole numbers (e.g., 42)
- Double: decimals (e.g., 3.14)
- String: text (e.g., "steel")
- Bool: true/false

Rule of thumb:
- Prefer `let` by default; switch to `var` only when you need mutation.
solution:
var hammerWeight = 10
print(hammerWeight)

hammerWeight = 12
print(hammerWeight)
title: Variables

cheatsheet:
Math Operators
- +, -, *, / for arithmetic
- % for remainder
- Compound assignment: +=, -=, *=, /=
hints: Arithmetic operators include +, -, *, /, and %.
Integer division uses / on Int values.
lesson:
Lesson: Math & Assignment
Arithmetic operators work on numeric types like Int and Double.

Operators:
- + (add), - (subtract), * (multiply), / (divide), % (remainder)

Examples:
    let total = 1200 + 300
    let half = 9 / 2        // Int division: 4
    let exact = 9.0 / 2.0   // Double: 4.5
    let leftover = 9 % 2    // 1

Compound assignment:
- Update a variable in place.
    var heat = 1200
    heat += 200    // 1400
    heat *= 2      // 2800
solution:
print(a + b)
print(a - b)
print(a * b)
print(a / b)
print(a % b)
title: Basic Math

cheatsheet:
Math Operators
- +, -, *, / for arithmetic
- % for remainder
- Compound assignment: +=, -=, *=, /=
hints: Compound assignment updates a value in place (+=, -=, *=, /=).
print(...) outputs a value to the console.
lesson:
Lesson: Math & Assignment
Arithmetic operators work on numeric types like Int and Double.

Operators:
- + (add), - (subtract), * (multiply), / (divide), % (remainder)

Examples:
    let total = 1200 + 300
    let half = 9 / 2        // Int division: 4
    let exact = 9.0 / 2.0   // Double: 4.5
    let leftover = 9 % 2    // 1

Compound assignment:
- Update a variable in place.
    var heat = 1200
    heat += 200    // 1400
    heat *= 2      // 2800
solution:
heat += 5
print(heat)

heat -= 3
print(heat)

heat *= 2
print(heat)

heat /= 3
print(heat)
title: Compound Assignment

cheatsheet:
Strings
- String literals use double quotes
- Concatenate with +
- Interpolate with \(value)
hints: String concatenation uses the + operator.
Include a space so the two words don't run together.
lesson:
Lesson: Strings
Strings store text and are enclosed in double quotes.

Overview:
- Strings can be combined, searched, and formatted.
- Swift uses `String` for text values.

Create strings:
    let name = "Forge"
    let status: String = "Ready"

Concatenation:
- Use `+` to join strings.
    let message = "Forge" + " Ready"

Interpolation:
- Insert values with \(value) inside a string.
    let heat = 1500
    let report = "Heat: \(heat)"

Common operations:
- `.count` for length
- `.uppercased()` / `.lowercased()`
- `.contains("text")`
- `.hasPrefix("pre")` / `.hasSuffix("suf")`
solution:
let forgeWord = "Forge"
let statusWord = "Ready"
let message = forgeWord + " " + statusWord

print(message)
title: Strings & Concatenation

cheatsheet:

cheatsheet:
Booleans
- Bool values are true or false
- Comparisons return Bool
- Logical operators: &&, ||, !
description: Work with true and false values
hints: Bool represents true/false values.
print(...) outputs a value to the console.
lesson:
Lesson: Booleans & Logic
A Bool stores `true` or `false`. Comparisons produce Bool values.

Overview:
- Use comparison operators to build conditions.
- Combine conditions with logical operators.

Comparison operators:
- ==, !=, <, >, <=, >=
    let hot = temp >= 1400
    let same = metal == "Iron"

Logical operators:
- && (and): true only if both sides are true
- || (or): true if either side is true
- ! (not): flips a Bool

Grouping and precedence:
- Use parentheses to make intent clear.
- && runs before || if parentheses are omitted.

Example:
    let ready = (metal == "Iron" && temp >= 1400) || temp >= 1200
solution:
let isHeated: Bool = true
print(isHeated)
title: Booleans

cheatsheet:

- Comparisons return Bool
- Logical operators: &&, ||, !

true

print(a <= b)
print(b >= a)
title: Comparison Operators

cheatsheet:
Booleans
- Bool values are true or false
- Comparisons return Bool
- Logical operators: &&, ||, !
hints: && requires both conditions to be true; || requires either.
! flips a Bool to its opposite.
Print ready, then partialReady, then notReady.
lesson:
Lesson: Booleans & Logic
A Bool stores `true` or `false`. Comparisons produce Bool values.

Overview:
- Use comparison operators to build conditions.
- Combine conditions with logical operators.

Comparison operators:
- ==, !=, <, >, <=, >=
    let hot = temp >= 1400
    let same = metal == "Iron"

Logical operators:
- && (and): true only if both sides are true
- || (or): true if either side is true
- ! (not): flips a Bool

Grouping and precedence:
- Use parentheses to make intent clear.
- && runs before || if parentheses are omitted.

Example:
    let ready = (metal == "Iron" && temp >= 1400) || temp >= 1200
solution:
let ready = heatReady && toolsReady
let partialReady = heatReady || toolsReady
let notReady = !ready

print(ready)
print(partialReady)
print(notReady)
title: Logical Operators

cheatsheet:
Functions
- func name(param: Type) { ... }
- Return with -> Type
- Call by name with arguments
hints: Define a function with func, then call it by name.
The function body should print the word.
title: Function Basics

Functions

Multiple parameters look like mix(metal: String, weight: Int).
Call both functions in order.

Functions

hints: Functions that return a value use -> ReturnType.

title: Return Values

cheatsheet:
Core 1 Integration
- Use let for constants; var for values that change
- Compound assignment: +=, -=, *=, /=
- Comparisons produce Bool: ==, !=, <, >, <=, >=
- Logic: && (and), || (or), ! (not)
- Functions: func name(param: Type) -> ReturnType { ... }
- Interpolation: "Value: \(value)"
description: Combine variables, functions, math, and strings
hints: This task blends state, computation, and presentation in one flow.
You can store intermediate results before producing final output.
Formatted output can include values inside the text.
lesson:
Lesson: Core 1 Integration
Combine the core concepts into one readable flow.

Suggested structure:
1) Setup: constants and variables
2) Compute: math and functions
3) Decide: comparisons and boolean logic
4) Report: string interpolation

Example flow:
    let base = 1200
    var heat = base + 200
    let isHot = heat >= 1400
    let status = isHot ? "Hot" : "Warm"
    print("Heat: \(heat) (\(status))")

Tip:
- Store intermediate values to keep each step clear.
title: Integration Challenge 1

cheatsheet:

- Functions: func name(param: Type) -> ReturnType { ... }
- Interpolation: "Value: \(value)"
description: Core 1 capstone: combine the essentials in one task
hints: Separate setup, rule selection, and reporting into distinct steps.
Signature: isReady(metal: String, temperature: Int) -> Bool.
Combine comparisons with && and || to express the rule.
The final output should summarize the chosen ruleâ€™s result.
